case_id: State of Tamil Nadu v. Ravi (2006) 9 SCC 284
facts: Incident occurred on the night between 12.09.1993 and 13.09.1993.
Accused: A1-Ravi, A2-Gopal @ Krishnagopal (acquitted by Trial Court), A3-Perumal (acquitted by Trial Court).
Allegation: Accused trespassed into the house of the deceased, attacked her with weapons (billhook - Aruval), causing her death.
Motive alleged: Prior enmity related to a land dispute and previous quarrels between the deceased's family and the accused.
PW1 (Son of the deceased) and PW2 (another son of the deceased) were sleeping outside the house.
PW1 claimed to have witnessed the incident in the light of a chimney lamp.
PW1 raised an alarm, causing the accused to flee.
PW1 went to the Village Administrative Officer (VAO - PW8) around 6:00 AM on 13.09.1993 and gave a complaint (Ex. P-1).
FIR (Ex. P-13) registered based on Ex. P-1.
Investigating Officer (IO - PW14) conducted inquest (Ex. P-14), prepared observation mahazar (Ex. P-2), and seized bloodstained earth (M.O.6) and sample earth (M.O.7).
Post-mortem conducted by Dr. R. Selvaraj (PW9); report (Ex. P-4) noted multiple incised wounds, including fatal injuries to the neck.
Based on A1's alleged confessional statement (Ex. P-15), a bloodstained billhook (M.O.1) was recovered from bushes near his house under a mahazar (Ex. P-3).

Seized items sent for chemical examination; report (Ex. P-10) confirmed human blood on the billhook (M.O.1) and bloodstained earth (M.O.6), but blood group could not be determined due to disintegration.
Trial Court convicted A1 (Ravi) under Section 302 IPC and sentenced him to life imprisonment. A2 and A3 were acquitted.
A1 appealed to the High Court.
High Court acquitted A1, primarily disbelieving the eyewitness testimony of PW1 and finding the recovery of M.O.1 unreliable.
State of Tamil Nadu appealed the High Court's acquittal judgment to the Supreme Court.
ipc_sections: Section 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention)
Section 201 (Causing disappearance of evidence of offence, or giving false information to screen offender - Relevant to recovery aspect)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The High Court erred in disbelieving the direct eyewitness testimony of PW1, the son of the deceased, who credibly identified A1.
precedents: Vadivelu Thevar v. State of Madras (AIR 1957 SC 614) - Testimony of a single eyewitness can be sufficient for conviction if reliable.
State of U.P. v. Kishan Chand (2004) 7 SCC 629 - Relationship is not a factor affecting credibility if the testimony is otherwise reliable.
Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab (AIR 1953 SC 364) - Close relatives would normally not screen the real culprit and falsely implicate an innocent person.
elements: Presence of PW1 at the scene.
Credibility and consistency of PW1's testimony.

counter_arguments.loophole: PW1 is a close relative (son) and thus an interested witness. His testimony requires careful scrutiny and independent corroboration, which is lacking.
supporting_precedents: State of Rajasthan v. Kalki (1981) 2 SCC 752 - Court must be cautious while evaluating testimony of interested witnesses.
Hari Obula Reddy v. State of A.P. (1981) 3 SCC 675 - Need for corroboration of interested witness testimony in material particulars.
Sarwan Singh v. State of Punjab (AIR 1976 SC 2304) - Relationship combined with enmity requires careful scrutiny.

counter_arguments.loophole: Possibility of identification errors in dim chimney light from a distance, especially during a stressful event.
supporting_precedents: Wakil Singh v. State of Bihar (AIR 1981 SC 1392) - Conviction solely on identification in poor light is unsafe without corroboration.
Rangaswami v. State of T.N. (AIR 1989 SC 1137) - Identification evidence needs to be strong, especially if based on fleeting glimpse or poor lighting.

defense_arguments.argument: The High Court rightly acquitted A1 as the sole eyewitness (PW1) testimony was unreliable due to relationship, enmity, lack of independent corroboration, and questionable identification in dim light.
edge_cases: Appellate court's power to reverse acquittal is limited; requires compelling reasons and finding the trial court judgment perverse.
Benefit of doubt must go to the accused when evidence is unreliable or creates suspicion.
precedents: Chandrappa v. State of Karnataka (2007) 4 SCC 415 - Principles governing appeal against acquittal; appellate court should not interfere merely because another view is possible.
State of U.P. v. Ram Veer Singh (2007) 13 SCC 102 - Higher standard of proof required to overturn an acquittal.
Kali Ram v. State of H.P. (1973) 2 SCC 808 - Prosecution must prove guilt beyond reasonable doubt; suspicion cannot replace proof.

judgment.outcome: Appeal allowed. High Court judgment set aside. Trial Court judgment convicting A1 (Ravi) under Section 302 IPC restored.
reasoning: The Supreme Court found the High Court's reasons for discarding PW1's testimony to be flimsy and unsustainable.
PW1 was a natural witness (son sleeping outside). His presence was probable.
Identification in chimney light was possible at close range; PW1's testimony was consistent and corroborated by prompt lodging of complaint (Ex. P-1) which formed the basis of FIR.
Delay in lodging FIR was adequately explained (incident at night, went to VAO in the morning).
Relationship and enmity do not automatically discredit a witness; PW1's testimony was found credible after careful scrutiny.
The recovery of M.O.1 (billhook) under Section 27, Evidence Act, was found reliable. Minor discrepancies in PW7's testimony were not fatal.
The fact that M.O.1 was found stained with human blood, though group couldn't be determined, was a valid corroborating circumstance, especially when considered with PW1's direct evidence.
Medical evidence (PW9, Ex. P-4) fully corroborated the manner of assault and weapon described by PW1.
The High Court had improperly interfered with the Trial Court's well-reasoned judgment of conviction by taking a perverse view of the evidence.
The chain of evidence, including eyewitness account, motive, recovery, and medical evidence, was complete and pointed towards the guilt of A1.
